'''Discrimination of excellence''' is the [[Injustice|unjust]] treatment of outperformers and [[Overachievement|overachievers]].<ref name = Puaschunder1>{{cite journal | vauthors = Puaschunder, Julia | title = Discrimination of Excellence: A Research Agenda| journal = Proceedings of the 14th International Research Association for Interdisciplinary Studies (RAIS) Conference at the Erdman Center of Princeton University | volume = 14 | issue = 1 | pages = 54–58 | date = August 2019 | doi = 10.2139/ssrn.3459603 | s2cid = 219357207| url = http://rais.education/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/009JP.pdf}}</ref> [[Discrimination]] against outperformers<ref>[https://www.hoagiesgifted.org/discrimination.htm"Kearney, Kathi, Discrimination against Excellence, Understanding Our Gifted, November/December 1993"]. 1993.</ref> includes the critique of unfair treatment in non-merit-based admissions practices, degree conferral or promotion standards.<ref name="Bazerman & Tenbrunsel (2011).">{{cite book|author1=Bazerman, M. H. |author2=Tenbrunsel, A. E.|year=2011|title=Blind Spots: Why we fail to do what's right and what to do about it|location = Princeton, NJ|publisher=Princeton University Press}}</ref> Unfair treatment of outperformers occurs when focusing away from merit or biases lead to economic [[inefficiency]] or suboptimal choice in the wake of intransparent, arbitrary or [[Nepotism|nepotistic]] decision-making. Discrimination against excellent students during admissions is thematized in [[Ivy League]] admission debates<ref name = Hartocollis>{{cite web | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/13/us/yale-discrimination.html | title = Justice Dept. Accuses Yale of Discrimination in Application Process | last = Hartocollis | first = Anemona | date = August 13, 2020 | work = New York Times}}</ref> and [[Students for Fair Admissions v. President and Fellows of Harvard College|legally scrutinized]] in the context of individuals outperforming on standardized college admission tests but not being admitted. Discrimination of excellence evidence is found in most outstanding students failing a PhD degree conferral<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.quora.com/If-I-fail-a-Ph-D-program-what-can-I-do | title = If I fail a Ph.D. program, what can I do?| last = Krotov| first = Vlad| date = July 10, 2020 | publisher = Quora}}</ref>{{User generated inline|certain=y|date=March 2021}} and intransparent promotion criteria systemically biasing against outperformers and overachievers.
==Foundation== [[Discrimination]] is [[Injustice|unjust]] or [[Prejudice|prejudicial treatment]] of different categories of people or things.<ref>[http://www.ourdocuments.gov/doc.php?flash=true&doc=97&page=transcript "Transcript of Civil Rights Act (1964)"]. Retrieved July 28, 2012.</ref> Attempts exist to legally abolish, economically counter-weight and societally alleviate the negative consequences of discrimination around the world.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://ec.europa.eu/info/aid-development-cooperation-fundamental-rights/your-rights-eu/know-your-rights/equality/non-discrimination_en | title = Non-discrimination | date = August 19, 2020 | publisher = European Commission}}</ref> The [[Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fifth]] and [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fourteenth Amendment]]s to the [[United States Constitution]] ban the federal and state governments from discriminating. The [[Employment discrimination law in the United States|United States Employment Discrimination]] laws seek to prevent discrimination based on race, sex, sexual orientation, religion, national origin, physical disability, and age by employers. The [[United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission]] lists as especially sensitive areas of discrimination attention age, disability, equal pay and compensation, genetic information, harassment, national origin, pregnancy, race and color, religion, retaliation, sex and sexual harassment.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.eeoc.gov/ | title = Equal Employment Opportunity Commission | publisher = Equal Employment Opportunity Commission}}</ref> The [[European Union]] introduced an Anti-Discrimination Directive<ref>{{cite web | url = https://ec.europa.eu/social/main.jsp?catId=166&langId=en | title = European Union Anti-Discrimination Directive | publisher = European Union}}</ref> to ban discrimination on the grounds of age, disability, religion or belief and sexual orientation. The [[Treaty of Lisbon|Lisbon Treaty on European Union and the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union]] serves as legal protection against discrimination acknowledging equal rights for all human to be treated unbiased and with equal fairness and dignity.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.europarl.europa.eu/factsheets/en/sheet/5/the-treaty-of-lisbon | title = Treaty of Lisbon | publisher = European Union}}</ref>
==Higher education discrimination== Discrimination of excellence includes the [[2019 college admissions bribery scandal|2019 college admission fraud scandals]], standardized admission test outperformers [[Students for Fair Admissions v. President and Fellows of Harvard College|suing a U.S. higher education institution]] and the [[United States Department of Justice]] scrutinizing higher education over potential systemic biases in college admission standards that would underweight transparent standardized testing criteria.<ref name="Hartocollis">{{cite web | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/13/us/yale-discrimination.html | title = Justice Dept. Accuses Yale of Discrimination in Application Process | last = Hartocollis | first = Anemona | date = August 13, 2020 | work = New York Times}}</ref>
[[University and college admission]] and promotion criteria are critical career gatekeeping events, in which unexpectedly overweighting intransparent, non-merit based criteria can result in merit-based outperformers underperforming in admissions. [[Discrimination]] [[bias]] can occur in merit-based up-or-out placement and promotion criteria in hierarchical rank orders, when performance is partially measured on intangible or intransparent performance criteria implying potential economic inefficiency.<ref name="Puaschunder1">{{cite journal | vauthors = Puaschunder, Julia | title = Discrimination of Excellence: A Research Agenda| journal = Proceedings of the 14th International Research Association for Interdisciplinary Studies (RAIS) Conference at the Erdman Center of Princeton University | volume = 14 | issue = 1 | pages = 54–58 | date = August 2019 | doi = 10.2139/ssrn.3459603 | s2cid = 219357207| url = http://rais.education/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/009JP.pdf}}</ref>
==Economic foundations<!-- Did this section defined, economic growth, social enhancement and cultural achievement, by only luxury consumption? -->== Outperformance<ref>{{cite web | url = https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/outperformance | title = Outperformance | publisher = Cambridge Dictionary}}</ref> is the foundation of excellence. [[Overachievement]] is related to [[investment]]s. Outperformance and overachievement are bases of the intellectual [[elites]]{{Clarify|date=January 2022}} and related to [[Luxury goods|luxury]] [[Consumption (economics)|consumption]].<ref name = Thomai>{{cite book | first = Thomaï | last = Serdari | editor-last = Armitage | editor-first = J. | editor2-last = Roberts | editor2-first = J. | chapter = Experiments in Suchness: Hiroshi Sugimoto’s Silk Shiki for Hermès | title = Critical Luxury Studies: Art, Design, Media| year = 2016 | pages = 130–50 | location = Edinburgh | publisher = Edinburgh University Press}}</ref>
[[Overachievement]] may instigate economic growth. [[John Maynard Keynes]]' [[multiplier effect]] attributes investments of overachievers as some of the drivers of economic growth. Investments of the striving elite multiply in economic spending in the overall economy.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_General_Theory_of_Employment,_Interest_and_Money | title = The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money | publisher = John Maynard Keynes}}</ref>{{Circular reference|date=November 2020}}
Consumption of the elite is an economic growth factor. [[Thorstein Veblen]]'s [[Trickle-down economics|trickling down]] of excellence emphasizes that [[Luxury goods|luxury]] [[Consumption (economics)|consumption]] is a driver of [[economic growth]] and accelerator of social enhancement and cultural advancement.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Theory_of_the_Leisure_Class | title = The Theory of Leisure Class | publisher = Thorstein Veblen}}</ref>{{Circular reference|date=November 2020}}
The [[The American Dream|American Dream]] ideals of striving to outperform are foundations of economic productivity.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.investopedia.com/ask/answers/061815/how-does-notion-american-dream-influence-us-economy.asp | title = How Does the American Dream Influence the US Economy? | publisher = Investopedia}}</ref>
==Historical foundations== Slowing down overachievers and abolishing intellectual outperformance has occurred throughout history. Various regimes attempted to eradicate, cut down or slow performance and discourage individual striving.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.thevintagenews.com/2016/08/25/priority-people-killed-academics-1970s-cambodia/ | title = People were killed for being academics during the 1970's in Cambodia | last = Radeska| first = Tijana | date = August 25, 2016 | publisher = The Vintage News}}</ref>
==Societal structure== Discrimination of excellence theory<ref name="Puaschunder1">{{cite journal | vauthors = Puaschunder, Julia | title = Discrimination of Excellence: A Research Agenda| journal = Proceedings of the 14th International Research Association for Interdisciplinary Studies (RAIS) Conference at the Erdman Center of Princeton University | volume = 14 | issue = 1 | pages = 54–58 | date = August 2019 | doi = 10.2139/ssrn.3459603 | s2cid = 219357207| url = http://rais.education/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/009JP.pdf}}</ref> integrates the 'übergroup'<ref>{{citation | vauthors = Puaschunder, Julia | title = Discrimination of Excellence, Copyright TXu002167333 / 2019-10-08 | date = October 2019 }}</ref> in the [[social psychology]] [[social identity theory]] categorization of society into so-called '[[ingroup]]s' and '[[outgroups]].'<ref name="Tajfel & Turner (1984).">{{cite book|author1=Tajfel, H. |author2=Turner, J. C.|year=1979|chapter= An integrative theory of intergroup conflict|editor1=W. G. Austin |editor2=S. Worchel|title=The social psychology of intergroup relations|pages=33–47|location=Monterey, CA|publisher=Brooks/Cole}}</ref>
